awd_titl_txt: Theory, Methods, and Empirical Analysis of Internet Bots
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most pressing challenges we face today is online hacking of communications by adversaries, including foreign adversaries. Non-human actors on social media platforms, that is accounts controlled by computer algorithms and colloquially known as Internet bots, are also playing an important part in this process. This project will conduct a major investigation of the role of Internet bots in public communications and political discussion. The project will have wide benefit for understanding how bots play a role in opinion and public policy.

The goal of this proposal therefore is to support the development of a theoretical framework for understanding the role of domestic and foreign non-human actors in online communications and conversation, methodological tools for both identifying bots and tracking their activity, and empirical analyses that test hypotheses from the researchers' theoretical framework using a unique collection of historical data. Theoretically, the project will develop a two-part framework that can be applied to both domestic and foreign adversaries. Methodologically, the researchers will build off of previous methods they have developed for identifying bots in one particular time and place to produce general methods for identifying bots in different times and places; we will also develop and verify new (and test existing) methods for tracking bot activity of the type their theories predict, and attempting to influence search engines and social media communications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most pressing questions in American politics today concerns the potential "hacking" of the 2016 presidential elections, and democratic debate in general, by foreign actors. While traditional media and human beings are undoubtedly important in hacking democracy, it is becoming increasingly clear that non-human actors on social media platforms, which are accounts controlled by computer algorithms and colloquially known as "bots", are also playing an important part in this process. However, the extent to which bots are present — and influential — in the electoral process and formation of public opinion remains an unanswered question. 

Our project makes three important contributions. First, we develop a theoretical framework for understanding the role of bots (both foreign and domestic) in democratic society. The framework distinguishes between "direct activity", which is intended to provide support for or opposition to policies or candidates, and "indirect activity", which attempts to manipulate the information environment to the benefit of a particular policy, candidate, or party by taking advantage of search optimization algorithms. 


Second, we develop novel methodological approaches for both identifying bots and tracking their activity. Existing bot detection tools that rely on the Twitter API, labeled data sets of bot accounts, and retweet or tweet-origin behaviors have significant and well-documented limitations. Instead, we opt for a conservative definition of bots that relies on “supervised machine learning” based on a large hand-labeled data set. More specifically, our dataset includes 1.2 billion tweets from January 1, 2015 – December 31, 2016. We recruited 15 undergraduate research assistants to hand label 6,693 accounts, and then trained a machine learning classifier to predict whether the accounts in our data were bots or human accounts. In total, we categorized over 6 million accounts, of which over 1.2 million were predicted to be bots. We then trained a classifier to identify the stance (i.e., positive, neutral, or negative) of the bot accounts towards then-candidates Trump, Clinton, and Sanders. 


Finally, our empirical analyses allow us to test hypotheses from our theoretical framework, focusing on the stance, strategy, and reach of partisan bot accounts (i.e. partisan referring to producing positive / negative messages in support of a single candidate). For stance, Clinton partisan accounts dramatically outnumbered other groups among non-bot accounts; however, this imbalance was strongly attenuated among bots. This finding provides evidence that bots could have helped to tilt the Twitter ecosystem toward Trump, although this tilting arguably had more to do with attenuating the prevalence of Clinton partisan human accounts. In terms of strategy, Clinton partisan bots – similar to Clinton partisan non-bots – focused primarily on criticizing Trump and engaged in cheerleading for Clinton to a much smaller extent. Unlike Clinton partisan accounts, the ones that helped Trump tended to be involved in both types of activities. As for reach, Trump partisan bots lag behind Clinton partisan accounts with both friends and followers, suggesting that Trump partisan accounts tend to be less connected with other accounts


Taken together, our project makes important contributions to the scholarly literature on and public discussion around the usage and role of bots in democratic politics. First, it provides a novel theoretical framework with which to evaluate bots' influence on the discussions around elections. This framework can support future research on the use of automated communications in electoral politics. Second, we develop an innovative method for bot classification that improves on current state-of-the-art classification strategies. This method is transparent, replicable, flexible, scalable, and suitable for retrospective analysis; importantly, it can be updated to study bots in future elections. And third, our findings provide new evidence around bots in the 2016 election, which can inform public and policy discussions around bots influence in U.S. elections.
